Authors:
Ole William Purvis, Samantha Fernandez-Brime, Martin
Westberg, Mats Wedin
Title:
Myriospora, a new genus for Antarctica with a world-wide key
to the species
Abstract:
Myriospora signyensis Purvis, Fdez.-Brime, Westberg &
Wedin is described from Signy Island, South Orkney Islands, Antarctica
where it occurs predominantly on quartz mica schist. This represents a
new record of the genus for Antarctica. The distinctive photobiont
arrangement places it within the genus Myriospora (formerly known as the
“Acarospora” smaragdula group, or Silobia). Characterized by having
large, distinctly elevated, sessile apothecia with a prominent margin,
and thallus which is usually lobed at the margins and variously
orange-red, rust-coloured or brown-pigmented. It is sister to M.
scabrida and, when rust coloured, resembles M. dilatata; both species
differ in having usually immersed apothecia. Within the South Orkney
Islands, the adjacent Coronation Island, with a similar lithology,
notably oceanic elements of the Scotia Metamorphic Complex, is most
likely to yield further localities for this currently rare, though
easily overlooked endemic species. A world-wide key to the 10 species
currently recognized in the genus is presented.
